Name: Inductive Reasoning - IND
Text: Okay, the user has shared a detailed description of a property management companys onboarding process for new rental properties. They want me to create a list of targeted, open-ended questions to clarify and improve understanding of this process. The questions should focus on missing details, decision criteria, roles, timing, and exception handling - but must avoid any SQL or technical implementation questions.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Let me analyze this process carefully. Its quite complex with multiple stages: documentation review, property manager assignment, marketing setup, tenant screening, and quality checks. The description mentions several key touchpoints but leaves some gaps I should probe.

Name: Abductive Reasoning - PE
Text: First, I need to identify where the process might be unclear. For example: - The documentation review stage mentions certificates of compliance but doesnt specify which regulations apply in different cities - The property manager assignment criteria seem important but vague (e.g., geographic specialization needs clarification) - The inspection phase has a dependency on landlord cooperation for repairs - Tenant screening mentions multiple interested tenants but doesnt explain the prioritization logic

Name: Hypothesis Generation - PE
Text: I should craft questions that uncover these ambiguities. The questions must be open-ended to encourage detailed responses, not yes/no questions. Since this is for process understanding, Ill avoid anything about systems or data - focus purely on human workflows and decision points.

Name: Heuristic Reasoning - IND
Text: Hmm, the user emphasized avoiding SQL queries, so Ill make sure all questions stay conceptual. Also need to cover all requested angles: missing details (like which documents are most frequently missing), decision criteria (how exactly they weigh manager experience), roles (who actually approves the final lease), timing (how long each phase typically takes), and exceptions (like special insurance cases).

Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: Let me structure questions around each major phase of the process described. For documentation: ask about common document failures. For manager assignment: dig into the weighting of criteria. For inspection: clarify repair escalation paths. For tenant screening: explore the multiple applicants scenario. For quality checks: confirm who does what in the audit.

Name: Inductive Reasoning - PE
Text: I should also consider pain points - the description mentions communication flows back and forth so asking about bottlenecks would be valuable. And since they mention landlords with unique requirements, Ill include a question about how they handle customization.

Name: Validation - IND
Text: checks description again Ah, they mention internal pricing models but dont say how often they update them. Thats a good question about market responsiveness.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: mental note Avoid leading questions. Instead of Do you have a standard timeline? ask How do you track and manage timeline expectations at each stage? Also must remember this is for a property management company, so questions should reflect industry realities - like fair housing compliance being non-negotiable. double-checking All questions must be open-ended: How do you..., What criteria..., Can you describe... - no do or is it questions.

Name: Heuristic Reasoning - PE
Text: Okay, compiling now: 5-7 key questions covering all critical gaps without overlapping. Prioritize the most impactful unknowns first.
